article.title: Comprehensive_Nuclear-Test-Ban_Treaty

template.arg: 180 days after it is ratified by {{Collapsible list|status
[[List of parties to the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty|183]]

[[List of parties to the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty|164]] (states that need to take further action for the treaty to enter into force: China, Egypt, India, Iran, Israel, North Korea, Pakistan, United States)
Arabic, Chinese, English, French, Russian and Spanish

article.paragraph: TheComprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty(CTBT) is amultilateral treatyby which states agree to ban allnuclear explosionsin all environments, for military or civilian purposes. It was adopted by theUnited Nations General Assemblyon 10 September 1996cite webhttp://www.un.org/documents/ga/res/50/ares50-245.htmResolution adopted by the general assembly:50/245. Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty17 September 19963 December 2011[[United Nations]]but it has not entered into force due to the non-ratification of eight specific states.
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: To date, over 2,000 nuclear tests have been carried out at different locations all over the world.cite web[[Preparatory Commission for the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty Organization]]2012http://www.ctbto.org/nuclear-testing/history-of-nuclear-testing/world-overview/page-1-world-overview/Nuclear testing world overview21 May 2012Arms control advocates had campaigned for the adoption of a treaty banning all nuclear explosions since the early 1950s, when public concern was aroused as a result of radioactive fall-out from atmospheric nuclear tests and the escalating arms race. Over 50 nuclear explosions were registered between 16 July 1945, when the first nuclear explosive test was conducted by the United States atWhite Sands Missile RangenearAlamogordo, New Mexico, and 31 December 1953.Prime Minister of IndiaPrime MinisterJawaharlal NehruNehruof India voiced the heightened international concern in 1954, when he proposed the elimination of all nuclear test explosions worldwide. However, within the context of theCold War, skepticism about the capability to verify compliance with a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty posed a major obstacle to any agreement.
article.heading: Partial Test Ban Treaty
article.paragraph: Limited success was achieved with the signing of thePartial Test Ban Treatyin 1963, which banned nuclear tests in the atmosphere, underwater and in space, but not underground. Neither France nor China signed the PTBT. However, the treaty was still ratified by the United States after an 80 to 19 vote in theUnited States Senate.cite webhttp://www.upi.com/Audio/Year_in_Review/Events-of-1963/University-of-Alabama/12295509434394-4/#title1963 Year In ReviewUPI.com3 December 20111963While the PTBT reduced atmospheric fallout, underground nuclear testing can also vent radioactivity into the atmosphere, and radioactivity released underground may seep into the ground water. Moreover, the PTBT had no restraining effects on the further development of nuclear warheads.cite webhttp://www.armscontrol.org/act/2003_10/LTBTArms Control AssociationDaryl Kimball and Wade BoeseJune 200921 May 2012Limited Test Ban Treaty Turns 40
article.heading: Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty
article.paragraph: A major step towardsnuclear proliferationnon-proliferationof nuclear weapons came with the signing of theNuclear Non-proliferation Treaty(NPT) in 1968. Under the NPT, non-nuclear weapon states were prohibited from, among other things, possessing, manufacturing or acquiring nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices. All signatories, including nuclear weapon states, were committed to the goal of totalnuclear disarmament. However, India, Pakistan and Israel have declined to sign the NPT on grounds that such a treaty is fundamentally discriminatory as it places limitations on states that do not have nuclear weapons while making no efforts to curb weapons development by declared nuclear weapons states.
article.heading: Negotiations for the CTBT
article.paragraph: Given the political situation prevailing in the subsequent decades, little progress was made in nuclear disarmament until the end of theCold Warin 1991. Parties to the PTBT held an amendment conference that year to discuss a proposal to convert the Treaty into an instrument banning all nuclear-weapon tests; with strong support from the UN General Assembly, negotiations for a comprehensive test-ban treaty began in 1993.
article.heading: Adoption of the CTBT
article.paragraph: Intensive efforts were made over the next three years to draft the Treaty text and its two annexes. However, theConference on Disarmament, in which negotiations were being held, did not succeed in reaching consensus on the adoption of the text. Under the direction of Prime MinisterJohn Howardand Foreign MinisterAlexander Downer,AustraliaCitation neededOctober 2013then sent the text to theUnited Nations General AssemblyinNew York, where it was submitted as a draft resolution.cite webComprehensive nuclear-test-ban treaty: draft resolutionhttp://unbisnet.un.org:8080/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session3 December 20116 September 1996[[United Nations]]On 10 September 1996, the Comprehensive Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT) was adopted by a large majority, exceeding two-thirds of the General Assembly's Membership.
article.heading: Obligations
article.paragraph: (Article I):cite webhttp://www.ctbto.org/fileadmin/content/treaty/treaty_text.pdfComprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty CTBTO4 December 2011[[CTBTO Preparatory Commission]]

list.listitem: Each State Party undertakes not to carry out anynuclear weapontest explosion or any other nuclear explosion, and to prohibit and prevent any such nuclear explosion at any place under its jurisdiction or control.
Each State Party undertakes, furthermore, to refrain from causing, encouraging, or in any way participating in the carrying out of any nuclear weapon test explosion or any other nuclear explosion.

article.heading: Status
article.paragraph:
furtherList of parties to the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban TreatyThe Treaty was adopted by theUnited Nations General Assemblyon 10 September 1996.It opened for signature in New York on 24 September 1996,United Nations Treaty Collection (2009). "Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty". Retrieved 23 August 2009.when it was signed by 71 States, including five of the eight thenList of states with nuclear weaponsnuclear-capable states. As of March 2015, 164 states haveRatification#Ratification of an international treatyratifiedthe CTBT and another 19 states have signed but not ratified it.cite web[[Preparatory Commission for the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty Organization]]2011http://www.ctbto.org/the-treaty/status-of-signature-and-ratification/Status of Signature and Ratification20 September 2011CitationDavid E. Hoffman 1 November 2011Supercomputers offer tools for nuclear testing — and solving nuclear mysteries [[The Washington Post]]; Nationalhttp://www.washingtonpost.com/national/national-security/supercomputers-offer-tools-for-nuclear-testing--and-solving-nuclear-mysteries/2011/10/03/gIQAjnngdM_story.html?wpisrcno30 November 2013
''In this news article, the number of states ratifying was reported as 154.

The treaty will enter into force 180 days after the 44 states listed in Annex 2 of the treaty have ratified it. These "Annex 2 states" are states that participated in the CTBTs negotiations between 1994 and 1996 and possessed nuclear power reactors or research reactors at that time.cite webhttp://www.ctbto.org/press-centre/highlights/2008/the-russian-federations-support-for-thecomprehensive-nuclear-test-ban-treaty/14-october-2008-page-2/?textonlyThe Russian Federation's support for the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty[[CTBTO Preparatory Commission]]20084 December 2011As of 2015, eight Annex 2 states have not ratified the treaty:People's Republic of ChinaChina,Egypt,Iran,Israeland theUnited Stateshave signed but not ratified the Treaty;India,North KoreaandPakistanhave not signed it.cite webSTATE DEPARTMENT TELEGRAM 012545 TO INTSUM COLLECTIVE, "INTSUM: INDIA: NUCLEAR TEST UNLIKELY"Nuclear Proliferation International History Projecthttps://digitalarchive.wilsoncenter.org/document/116347
article.heading: Monitoring of the CTBT
article.paragraph: geophysicsGeophysicaland other technologies are used to monitor for compliance with the Treaty:forensic seismology,hydrophonehydroacoustics,infrasound, andradionuclidemonitoring. The technologies are used to monitor the underground, the waters and the atmosphere for any sign of a nuclear explosion. Statistical theories and methods are integral to CTBT monitoringproviding confidence in verification analysis. Once the Treaty enters into force, on site inspection will be provided for where concerns about compliance arise.

TheComprehensive Test Ban Treaty Organization Preparatory CommissionPreparatory Commissionfor theComprehensive Test Ban Treaty Organization(CTBTO), an international organization headquartered inVienna,Austria, was created to build the verification regime, including establishment and provisional operation of the network of monitoring stations, the creation of an international data centre, and development of the On Site Inspection capability.

The monitoring network consists of 337 facilities located all over the globe. As of May 2012, more than 260 facilities have been certified. The monitoring stations register data that is transmitted to the international data centre in Vienna for processing and analysis. The data are sent to states that have signed the Treaty.cite webhttp://www.ctbto.org/press-centre/press-releases/2009/us-nuclear-security-administrator-dagostinovisits-the-ctbto/US nuclear security administrator dagostino visits the CTBTO4 December 201115 September 2009[[CTBTO Preparatory Commission]]
article.heading: Nuclear testing after CTBT adoption
article.paragraph: Three countries have tested nuclear weapons since the CTBT opened for signature in 1996. India and Pakistan both carried out two sets of tests in 1998. North Korea carried out three announced tests in 2006, 2009 and 2013. All three North Korean tests were picked up by the International Monitoring System set up by theComprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty Organization Preparatory Commission.cite web[[Preparatory Commission for the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty Organization]]2012http://www.ctbto.org/press-centre/highlights/2007/the-ctbt-verification-regime-put-to-the-test-the-event-in-the-dprk-on-9-october-2006/page-1/?FsizeHighlight 2007: The CTBT Verification Regime Put to the Test – The Event in the DPRK on 9 October 200621 May 2012cite web[[Preparatory Commission for the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty Organization]]2012http://www.ctbto.org/press-centre/highlights/2009/experts-sure-about-nature-of-the-dprk-event/?FsizePress Release June 2009: Experts Sure About Nature of the DPRK Event21 May 2012
